intro: Gomphrena mandonii, commonly known as the desert gayfeather, is a flowering plant native to arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its striking, spiky, pink or purple flower heads that resemble plumes, which are composed of tiny, tubular flowers. The plant has narrow, gray-green leaves that are adapted to reduce water loss in hot, dry environments. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or sandy habitats. Gomphrena mandonii is a member of the Amaranthaceae family, which includes other ornamental and edible plants.
